abstract.value:
George Watt served as a political
        commissar in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade during the Spanish Civil War and later as a
        sergeant in the Army Air Force during World War II. This collection consists chiefly of
        letters written to and from George Watt during these conflicts.

p.value:
Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Tamiment Library & Robert F.
        Wagner Labor Archives for more information and to schedule an appointment,
        tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder
        number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

Materials from the 2004, 2005, and 2012 accretions were donated by Dan Lynn Watt and Molly
        Lynn Watt. Donation of a CD recording of letters between George and Ruth Watt donated by Dan
        Watt in 2012. The accession number associated with this donation is 2013.027.

This collection consists chiefly of letters written to and from George Watt during World
        War II and the Spanish Civil War. There is also a page proof of Watt's book <emph
          render="italic">The Comet Connection : Escape from Hitler's Europe</emph> (1990). First
        donation: seven handwritten World War II era letters. Five are from George Watt, then in the
        US Army; three of these are to Milt Wolff. Two letters are about George Watt. Also included
        is a page proof of Watt's book <emph render="italic">The Comet Connection : Escape from
          Hitler's Europe</emph> (1990). Second donation (Dec. 2004): c. 300 letters written by
        George Watt during World War II to his wife, Margaret Watt. Third donation: (Dec. 2005): c.
        300 World War II letters to and from George Watt (some from his wife, Margaret Watt, and
        some from Milt Wolff) and miscellaneous documents. Fourth donation: (Oct. 2012): c. 50
        (mostly handwritten) letters written by George Watt between July 1937 and December 1938,
        after he returned from Spain. The majority of the letters are written to his first wife,
        Ruth Watt, but there are also letters to Terry Levin, a close friend; his sister, Mae Kwatt;
        and other family members. This accretion also includes a typewritten text of a radio speech
        written by George Watt in February 1939. A fifth donation of a CD recording of readings of
        George and Ruth Watt's letters was added in 2013.
